node.title: There is nucleation signal, but the corresponding reserved order parameter can not be observed
node.bodyText:
Here is my input file：



The nucleation signal can be seen, but the corresponding order parameter gr9 is 0
Does this mean that the preserving order parameter of the newly inserted nucleation is GR0？
@permcody on grain nucleation

If I recall correctly, once you see that message, the GrainTracker will "move" your grain from the reserved order parameter to one of the "normal" order parameters to continue evolving it. Try looking at the reserved order parameter (in your case gr9) one time step earlier, unless your insertion is happening in this step. In any case, visualizing the staging area may not be very interesting. There should be a message about which OP the new grain got remapped to right after that message.
I assume you found the page on Nucleation here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Nucleation/DiscreteNucleation.html
There are also a few test cases checked in for nucleation that are very small and run quickly. You might run those and observe the behavior along with the screen output. It will help you understand a bit more of what's going on in your simulation.

https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Nucleation/DiscreteNucleation.html
I learned about nucleation on the above page, but there were no examples of polycrystalline nucleation, so I couldn't get more specific guidance.
And in my case, at Step 27, there's a nucleation signal:

But I couldn't find the output of gr7 in the visualizations of steps 26 and 27, and there was no signal like a rema.
There is no output from GR9 until step 30, and there is always evolution：

Oh… I don’t like seeing those “split grain detected” messages. Something
isn’t right with what’s being detected.

Either I or somebody else is going to have to dig into the code, with this
input. I hate to say this, but you might try a different random seed to see
if you can get past this. It might be the case that I just disable split
grain detection in a simulation where we shouldn’t expect that (most if not
all Voroni-based initial conditions).
…
On Wed, Jun 19, 2024 at 7:22 PM YXY101676 ***@***.***> wrote:

 https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Nucleation/DiscreteNucleation.html
 I learned about nucleation on the above page, but there were no examples
 of polycrystalline nucleation, so I couldn't get more specific guidance.
 And in my case, at Step 27, there's a nucleation signal:
 image.png (view on web)
 <https://github.com/idaholab/moose/assets/154942901/7e154485-1b50-4be7-8f0f-ece5ad6a5da1>
 But I couldn't find the output of gr7 in the visualizations of steps 26
 and 27, and there was no signal like a rema.
 There is no output from GR9 until step 30, and there is always evolution：
 image.png (view on web)
 <https://github.com/idaholab/moose/assets/154942901/8f84cb8a-336c-463d-b144-d6d4f03b5162>
 image.png (view on web)
 <https://github.com/idaholab/moose/assets/154942901/46799ef4-e5cd-4fdc-a20f-c361b7cc41bc>

 —
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#27935 (reply in thread)>,
 or unsubscribe
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAXFOIGJNEO7LLF2RXCQZMDZIIVENAVCNFSM6AAAAABJRFLAHKVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43SRDJONRXK43TNFXW4Q3PNVWWK3TUHM4TQMRTGEZDO>
 .
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID:
 ***@***.***>
So I should change the initial grain structure to avoid the crack problem? What does this GR9 stand for? Aren't they new nucleated grains
Does anyone use moose to complete the nucleation and grain growth process of polycrystalline structure? This is very important to me

While definitely not a solution, changing the initial grain structure may get you past the immediate problem so it’s worth a try.  GR9 is simply the name of one of your order parameter fields. In your input file your input file, you requested 10 order parameters with a prefix of “gr” so they are gr0-gr9. The highest numbered order parameter will be the reserved field for nucleation. So to answer your last question. It’s not a nucleated grain, it’s the field that holds your grains as the are starting to nucleate until they are large enough to recognize and transfer.
We have done polycrystalline simulations with grain nucleation. @dschwen, do we have an sample input files for that kind of sim?
But the holdtime I set it to 0, it shouldn't actually be here this long
To what extent will be mapped by graintracker, is it set by the reserve parameter

node.title: Fractional inverse Laplacian in energy
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am working on a phase separation problem for block copolymers. Based on the basic phase field equations, I have a $E_d$ term that has a fractional inverse Laplacian operator. The complete equation is given here -

where $-\Delta^{-1/2}$ is the fractional inverse Laplacian.
I have a general understanding that Laplacian is implemented in the electromagnetism module, but is there an instance of its inverse? How can I implement it in my MOOSE code?

node.title: In GDB, how can I find out which element is currently being calculated and its material information?
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello moose community! I'm encountering a bit of numerical problems with my current models, so I'd like to check step by step how they change.
I've found that gdb might meet my needs, but what's in the debugging page isn't quite enough for me.
I've now got gdb running successfully and can perform breakpoints and stepping where I want.
However, when I stop at a particular location in a particular file and want to query some data about the current computational process (e.g. _current_elem,_displacement,_stress, etc.), I don't really know how to get them.
I did query the relevant commands, such as info locals, info args, info variables, but I didn't find any of the above required data. Can anyone help me with this? Any suggestions are much appreciated!
Sincerely.
Sen Huang

Hello
These will be available in the computeValue / computeQpProperty etc, the innermost call in the element loops.
They wont be elsewhere and they wont be initialized.
info locals

should work. Else you can use p <name of variable> iirc
Guillaume

node.title: Whether support FMI
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Does MOOSE support FMI(Functional Mock-up Interface)?
If it does, could you please share a guidline or some instances to me? If not, is there any interface or method for co-simulation with other tools like OpenModeilca, FEniCS and etc.
Thank you!

Hello
No we don't.
But the capabilities offered by FMI should be easy to replicate.
You can wrap your moose solves in a Python script and read the post processing data output to file. FMI only supports scalar values so you don't have to worry about fields.
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for you quick answer!
I don't know how to wrap MOOSE slover in a Python script, and FMU make of '.dll' or '.c' file, is Python script availible? Could you please describe the process more detail (a example should be better)? Thanks a lot!

ah so if you are looking for a FMU we don't provide that either and that's harder to do for now. FMI is easier to replicate without following the standard. You ll have to manually wrap around MOOSE using the python os or subprocess modules.
An example would be, once you have compiled the heat transfer module for example:
import subprocess
import csv

# Run the simulation
subprocess.call("heat_transfer-opt -i diffusion.i", shell=True)

# Parse the output file
import csv
with open('diffusion_out.csv') as csvfile:
    reader = csv.reader(csvfile, delimiter=',')
    for row in reader:
        print(', '.join(row))

Thank you! I want to wrap it as FMU so that make MOOSE co-simulation with other electromagnetic simulation tools (seems not found this module in MOOSE) like OpenModelica else.
I'll try this way, it's like run MOOSE by python script and get the results after the simulation finished. Can I get data of each time-steps and set parameters during the simulation progress dynamicly?

We have an EM module, it just only does waves for now.
The csv file will have the data for each time step.
To change parameters dynamically, there's two options:

run each input with a single time step and use the restart capabilities
try to figure out the web server. I dont have experience on that

Thank you a lot!
Where can I find the guidline for csv file's settings to get the data what I want? For example, I want to get the temperature value at some particular points by time steps in 3D (mesh type is exodus mesh file).

use the postprocessors for that. A PointValue will do what you want
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Postprocessors/index.html

Thank you!
Is the value of point =  means 'x y z' of coordinate. When I set it as point = '5 5 5', I got below error:
`The following error occurred in the object "test_point", of type "PointValue".
No element located at (x,y,z)=(       5,        5,        5) in PointValue Postprocessor named: test_point
`
Only when I set it as '0 0 0' then it can runing correct.
I use exodus mesh file instead of generate mesh by MOOSE. How can I get the value of a particular point or a plane?
Besides, I just get 1 step value by this way. How can I get more value by time steps?
if you run your simulation with --mesh-only what does it report for the mesh bounding box?

Part of its report:
`Mesh Information:
elem_dimensions()={3}
spatial_dimension()=3
n_nodes()=52815
n_local_nodes()=13452
n_elem()=34746
n_local_elem()=8688
n_active_elem()=34746
n_subdomains()=77
n_elemsets()=0
n_partitions()=4
n_processors()=4
n_threads()=1
processor_id()=0
is_prepared()=true
is_replicated()=true
Mesh Bounding Box:
Minimum: (x,y,z)=( -0.3, -0.3, -0.01)
Maximum: (x,y,z)=( 0.3, 0.3, 0.004)
Delta: (x,y,z)=( 0.6, 0.6, 0.014)
Mesh Element Type(s):
HEX8
Mesh Nodesets:
Nodeset 1, 32238 nodes
Bounding box minimum: (x,y,z)=( -0.3, -0.3, 0)
Bounding box maximum: (x,y,z)=( 0.3, 0.3, 0.004)
Bounding box delta: (x,y,z)=( 0.6, 0.6, 0.004)
............................
Mesh Sidesets:
Sideset 1, 31470 sides (QUAD4), 30990 elems (HEX8), 32231 nodes
Side volume: 0.687315
Bounding box minimum: (x,y,z)=( -0.3, -0.3, 0)
Bounding box maximum: (x,y,z)=( 0.3, 0.3, 0.004)
Bounding box delta: (x,y,z)=( 0.6, 0.6, 0.004)
Sideset 2 (r1_wall), 132 sides (QUAD4), 80 elems (HEX8), 155 nodes
Side volume: 0.003444
Bounding box minimum: (x,y,z)=( 0.1815, -0.236, -0.01)
Bounding box maximum: (x,y,z)=( 0.2685, -0.214, 0)
Bounding box delta: (x,y,z)=( 0.087, 0.022, 0.01)
...................................
Mesh Edgesets:
None
Mesh Subdomains:
Subdomain 1: 32900 elems (HEX8, 32900 active), 50073 active nodes
Volume: 0.00144
Bounding box minimum: (x,y,z)=( -0.3, -0.3, 0)
Bounding box maximum: (x,y,z)=( 0.3, 0.3, 0.004)
Bounding box delta: (x,y,z)=( 0.6, 0.6, 0.004)
..............................................`

your mesh only extends to Bounding box maximum: (x,y,z)=( 0.3, 0.3, 0.004)
so5,5,5 is too far.
You need to check the coordinates

FMI only supports scalar values so you don't have to worry about fields.

This is true for FMI 1.0 and 2.0, not for 3.0, see https://fmi-standard.org/docs/3.0.1/

Thanks for sharing the link!
do you mind pasting a section number?
https://fmi-standard.org/docs/3.0.1/#fmu-variables

Thank you!
So to do a "Transfer" in the MOOSE sense ( https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Transfers/index.html ) we would send 4 variables (one for each of x, y, z and the variable) and the either the receiving FMU or some wrapping code in between would translate that to the potentially non-matching (because the number of cells are different, coarser mesh for example) receiving code?
Or is the conversion (between different representations of the same field, again due to non-matching geometries/meshes) codified in the standard as well?
from what I see in the standard with the get and set routines, I would expect the code in between to do the conversion.
Or be limited to fully-matching field representations (a CopyTransfer in MOOSE-speak)
Looking around it seems people are planning to codify the representation of variables (fields?) here
https://github.com/modelica/fmi-ls-struct
and their communication here
https://github.com/modelica/fmi-ls-bus
am I correct?

Hm. I do not know anything obout Moose, so the "translation" is difficult for me.
The FMI Interface does not know anything about meshes etc. The variable are typically used as "signals", not as spacially distributed fields in the multy-physics sense.
But your could give new meaning to certain array variables in a layered standard on top of FMI (see https://fmi-standard.org/docs/3.0.1/#VersioningLayered and https://www.conftool.com/modelica2023/index.php/Bertsch-Beyond_FMI_-_Towards_New_Applications_with_Layered_Standards-132_a.pdf?page=downloadPaper&filename=Bertsch-Beyond_FMI_-_Towards_New_Applications_with_Layered_Standards-132_a.pdf&form_id=132&form_version=final  for the concept of layered standards) for your use cases - this is what is done for in fmi-ls-bus and fmi-ls-struct.
Before you go the a spatially distributed multi-phyiscs-extension of FMI, I think exchanging avarage values e.g.  on surfaces with a system simulation tool via signals is the lower hanging fruit. See e.g.  https://www.conftool.com/modelica2023/index.php/Willeke-A_preCICE-FMI_Runner_to_Couple_FMUs_to_PDE-Based_Simulations-175_a.pdf?page=downloadPaper&filename=Willeke-A_preCICE-FMI_Runner_to_Couple_FMUs_to_PDE-Based_Simulations-175_a.pdf&form_id=175&form_version=final

Hello
No we don't. But the capabilities offered by FMI should be easy to replicate.
You can wrap your moose solves in a Python script and read the post processing data output to file. FMI only supports scalar values so you don't have to worry about fields.
Guillaume

Hi,
I am also interested in wrapping MOOSE into a FMI object. So far we are able to do what @GiudGiud suggested above. In our case MOOSE is the master app and Modelica the slave, however the simulation is quite expensive as the Modelica simulation needs to restart in every simulation step. A FMI would be a nice fix to improve performance.
@chrbertsch and @richman2024 are you aware of any FEM or CFD code that has been wrapped into a FMU?
Thanks!

they have the list of codes there
https://fmi-standard.org/tools/
there's quite a few

Hello
No we don't. But the capabilities offered by FMI should be easy to replicate.
You can wrap your moose solves in a Python script and read the post processing data output to file. FMI only supports scalar values so you don't have to worry about fields.
Guillaume

Hi, I am also interested in wrapping MOOSE into a FMI object. So far we are able to do what @GiudGiud suggested above. In our case MOOSE is the master app and Modelica the slave, however the simulation is quite expensive as the Modelica simulation needs to restart in every simulation step. A FMI would be a nice fix to improve performance.
@chrbertsch and @richman2024 are you aware of any FEM or CFD code that has been wrapped into a FMU? Thanks!

Hi @burritotukituki ,
I am also thinking about getting Modelica to talk with my MOOSE-based application. I understand how to get and read the output csv file from a python script, but I am not familiar with the restart option in MOOSE. Will you be able to give some detailed tutorial on how you use MOOSE as the master app and Modelica as the slave? I think it will serve as a good starting point for me.
Besides, do you end up succeeding in wrapping MOOSE into a FMI object? If so, can you please give me some suggestions on how it can be done?
Thank you so much!

@chrbertsch and @richman2024 are you aware of any FEM or CFD code that has been wrapped into a FMU?

You can filter the FMI tools list with "FMI" or "CFD" https://fmi-standard.org/tools/.
Mostly the import of Functional Mock-up Units is supported by FMI and CFD tools.
See also  https://www.3ds.com/support/hardware-and-software/simulia-system-information/compatibility/co-simulation/ "Abaqus 2019 and later use the FMI 2.0 standard for communicate with Dymola."
Regarding the export of FMUs many tools can generate reduced-order or surrogate models as FMUs (e.g. Ansys Twin Builder, Optislang ...),
But there are als tools such as XFlow that support the export of the unreduced model as FMU

node.title: How to compute plastic strain rate
node.bodyText: I need to compute some plastic work requiring a plastic strain rate. However, I looked at the website and the source codes, and currently, there is no way to retrieve the plastic strain rate directly.

Use Debug/show_material_props to see if it s computed as a material property
If so, then a MaterialRealAux (or the appropriate type depending on the data type of that property) will do the trick
it seems like plastic strain rate is not computed as a material property. Can (p - p_old)/delta_t work? p is the plastic strain and delta_t is the time increment.
If you are using an implicit Euler time integrator, the default, then this will be correct
thanks!

node.title: The deformation process cannot be displayed directly using paraview post-processing
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose Experts,
I am studying the example about the plasticity part of the crystal and now have some questions. When I run the exception.i file ( moose/modules/solid_mechanics/test/tests/crystal_plasticity/stress_update_material_based/exception.i) , I can't see the deformation over time like in the other examples when I put the results into the paraview software for visualisation.

I want to get a deformation display like the other examples, how do I go about doing that?
I would greatly appreciate any insights or suggestions from the community to help resolve this issue.
Thank you very much for your time and consideration.

Hello
I m not sure what you mean. Do you mean the displacements should be called disp instead of u ?
Guillaume

Thank you very much for being able to reply to me, I'm sorry it took so long to get back to you, it's not the name of the displacement but how it shows up in the visualisation. As in the original question, you can see the shape change over time in the other examples, but not in the result of running the exception.i file.

I think that's tied to the name.
You need paraview to recognize that the vector is a vector of the displacements of nodes
https://discourse.paraview.org/t/displacement-of-mesh-operator-in-paraview/11590/6
Either that or you can output the displaced mesh by specifying use_displaced_mesh in the Output
Thank you very much for your answer, I will try this!

node.title: Help in understanding structure of code

node.bodyText:
Hello
yes it does. This is for an anisotropic diffusivity, where the x y and z components could be different, but the diffusivity tensor is still diagonal.
Guillaume
Thank you. Does it transfer as a revised grad_u or a diffusivity?

what do you mean by transfer?
It's a diffusive flux (D * grad_u)
Is the code as written redundant? Is the "return grad_u * diffusivity" needed or is the end result of the code simply "d_grad_u(i) *= diffusivity(i);" ?
In the previous section prior to defining d_grad_u, could the statement just have simply been "return grad_u", then in the subject section, "RealVectorValue d_grad_u = grad_u"?

node.title: Crystal plasticity model
node.bodyText:
I am using the crystal plasticity kernel and the 'trial_xtalpl' as shown below is a required parameter of the crystal_plasticity_models object. I need more information about what 'trial_xtalpl' is but I can't find it. Is there a place to get more information on that, thanks.
@dschwen @vprithiv @GiudGiud
[Materials]
[stress]
type = ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress
crystal_plasticity_models = 'trial_xtalpl'
tan_mod_type = exact
[]
[]

Hello
Here it s just the name of another object in that input file I think.
Can you please paste the whole input file?

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'ux uy uz'
[]

[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 3
  elem_type = HEX8
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [fp_zz]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [e_zz]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [gss]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [tdisp]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 0.01*t
  []
[]

[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic/all]
  strain = FINITE
  add_variables = true
  generate_output = stress_zz
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [fp_zz]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = fp_zz
    rank_two_tensor = plastic_deformation_gradient
    index_j = 2
    index_i = 2
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [e_zz]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = e_zz
    rank_two_tensor = total_lagrangian_strain
    index_j = 2
    index_i = 2
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [gss1]
    type = MaterialStdVectorAux
    variable = gss
    property = slip_resistance
    index = 0
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [symmy]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = uy
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0
  []
  [symmx]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = ux
    boundary = left
    value = 0
  []
  [symmz]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = uz
    boundary = back
    value = 0
  []
  [tdisp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = uz
    boundary = front
    function = tdisp
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorCP
    C_ijkl = '1.684e5 1.214e5 1.214e5 1.684e5 1.214e5 1.684e5 0.754e5 0.754e5 0.754e5'
    fill_method = symmetric9
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress
    crystal_plasticity_models = 'trial_xtalpl'
    tan_mod_type = exact
    maximum_substep_iteration = 200
    use_line_search = true
    min_line_search_step_size = 0.01
  []
  [trial_xtalpl]
    type = CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate
    number_slip_systems = 12
    slip_sys_file_name = input_slip_sys.txt
    resistance_tol = 0.01
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [stress_zz]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = stress_zz
  []
  [fp_zz]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = fp_zz
  []
  [e_zz]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = e_zz
  []
  [gss]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = gss
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  dt = 0.05
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'

  petsc_options_iname = -pc_hypre_type
  petsc_options_value = boomerang
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  nl_rel_step_tol = 1e-10
  dtmax = 10.0
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-10
  end_time = 1
  dtmin = 0.02
  num_steps = 10
  nl_abs_step_tol = 1e-10
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

It's this object
  [trial_xtalpl]
    type = CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate
    number_slip_systems = 12
    slip_sys_file_name = input_slip_sys.txt
    resistance_tol = 0.01
  []
Does that mean I can choose any name I want for that block? Does trial_xtalpl do whatever [trial_xtalpl] block executes?
yes. You can change that name to be whatever you want

@Emmanuel-324
CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate is the object we are dealing with, search in the codebase to see implementation. Please be aware that the model parameters have default values within this implementation. If you want to change that, you need to assign those parameters within the input file, like:
[trial_xtalpl]
type = CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate
number_slip_systems = 12
gss_initial = 120
slip_sys_file_name = input_slip_sys.txt
resistance_tol = 0.01
[]
Thanks @GiudGiud , @vprithiv . I am also looking for some information on the 'CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase' in the MOOSE documentation but I can't find it. Any help?

Check this one, most of the framework is in Compute Multiple Crystal Plasticity Stress
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/crystal_plasticity/ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress.html
CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase is the base class, I think it has the general framework. You can directly check the code in the codebase.

_=/usr/bin/env
What is the error?

FYI, when trying to post pre-formated text, GitHub honors the three tick header:
       ```pre
       stuff in here followed by three ticks on a new line:
       ```

What does the following return?
$FC -show
which $($FC -show | cut -d\  -f1)
(fyi, I am now using GitHub's syntax markdown, by supplying):
     ```bash
     bash commands are syntax highlighted
     ```

sohar@DESKTOP-RPC0OMG:~/projects/moose/scripts$ $FC -show
ch $($FC -show | cut -d\  -f1)--------------------------------------------------------------------------
No underlying compiler was specified in the wrapper compiler data file
(e.g., mpicc-wrapper-data.txt)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
sohar@DESKTOP-RPC0OMG:~/projects/moose/scripts$ which $($FC -show | cut -d\  -f1)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
No underlying compiler was specified in the wrapper compiler data file
(e.g., mpicc-wrapper-data.txt)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

I think you might not have a Fortran compiler installed? I've never seen a return like that before. This might be as easy as using apt-get install. However, I do not know the exact line you will need, as it looks like you are using a custom built OpenMPI (because it is sitting in /usr/local and not /usr/bin).
If you do have gfortran installed:
which gfortran
...It looks like your custom built OpenMPI was not configured to use it or something like that? Can you elaborate on your installation of OpenMPI a bit more? I feel this might also be something related to the Cuda compilers also installed?

sohar@DESKTOP-RPC0OMG:~/projects/moose/scripts$ sudo apt-get install gfortran
[sudo] password for sohar:
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree... Done
Reading state information... Done
gfortran is already the newest version (4:11.2.0-1ubuntu1).
0 upgraded, 0 newly installed, 0 to remove and 24 not upgraded.
sohar@DESKTOP-RPC0OMG:~/projects/moose/scripts$ which gfortran
/usr/bin/gfortran

I downloaded the installation package manually in order to keep the version of openmpi and other computers the same. Maybe this is the problem, I will try to reinstall openmpi.
Would it be possible to link the OpenMPI instructions you were following? I am curious!

I also had the same problem in ubuntu of VMware. Before, my solution was to update the version of openmpi, but now this method did not work. I did not see similar errors in the forum, so I hope you can provide some suggestions.

You need a fortran compiler.
It seems while the F90, FC, F77 environment variables are set, there's not a working fortran compiler there

hmmm... this should have said FAIL instead of OK
F90 version:

Python Sanity Checks

Edit:
Oh I see why it didn't fail. I am checking on the presence of the variable being set. Not actually checking if the variable is pointing to a working binary.

I've downloaded fortran
sohar@sohar-vm:~/projects/moose/scripts$ gfortran -v

node.title: Output boundary heat flux
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
How to output the boundary heat flux in the process of 3D heat transfer calculation. It's best to keep it in Lagrange auxvariable. thanks a lot

Hello
This should work unless you used an exotic FE discretization
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/SideDiffusiveFluxIntegral.html
这是来自QQ邮箱的假期自动回复邮件。你好，已收到你的形势与政策作业，祝你天天愉快~
你好
